texts.definition: The elimination or change of ownership of an game element.
markups: <style="Definition">The elimination or change of ownership of an game element.</style>

Many games contain events that remove game elements from play. Traditionally this is called to <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> the pieces, even if this may mean removing them or transforming them to so they become another player's pieces.

Note: While Board Games typically use the term Capture, Real-Time Games instead uses Eliminate. For this pattern collection, Eliminate is seen as a more specific form of Capture due to being a newer form of the same phenomena.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> show many different ways to <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> enemy pieces: <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hnefatafl">Hnefatafl</link></style> by surrounding a piece from two opposing sides (four for the king), <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> by completely enclosing an enemy group of stones, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stratego">Stratego</link></style> by replacing a piece with ones own. It is also worth noticing that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> allows players to make their own groups be captured for larger tactical reasons while there exists specific rules for which pieces can <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> which pieces in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stratego">Stratego</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Qix">Qix</link></style> allows the player to catch computer-controlled units by enclosing them in the smaller area of the two areas that are created by outlining a path in the unmarked part of the game area.

Priests in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Age%20of%20Empires%20series">Age of Empires series</link></style> can convert pieces controlled by other players as their main offensive action.
Capture the Flag modes in the Quake series and the Team Fortress series pitch teams against each other in contest over game elements (flags and briefcases respectively).

Three main decisions need to be done for each type of Capture allowed in games: which game elements can perform the Capture, which game elements can be the targets, and what actions are required to activate the Capture. MacGuffins work well as game elements to Capture when this is the primary focus of the game and they are not destroyed when captured. Otherwise Units are the most common type of game elements used, although Avatars make rare appearance, e.g. through King pieces in Chess (Units will be referred to mostly in the following but unless explicitly noted this could be replaced by MacGuffins or Avatars). Many games, e.g. Chess, Go, and Draughts, make no distinction of which game elements can Capture, but the Bombs in Stratego cannot move and therefore not actively try to Capture other pieces. Likewise, most pieces can be the target of Capture actions but Hnefatafl has special requires for capturing the king piece and Stratego as special rules for which Units can Capture which. Combined with the Imperfect Information in Stratego, this makes capturing there have an element of Risk/Reward.

Parlett describes in some detail 7 ways to Capture in board games: Custodianship, Displacement, Enclosure, Intervention, Leap, Approach, and Withdrawal. Custodianship consist of flanking a target by placing Units in Connection with it. This example of Combos can be found in ordinary Captures in Hnefatafl. Displacement is simply using Movement to enter the space occupied by the target and remove it, as is done for example in Chess. Enclosure, used in Go, requires placing Units in all spaces adjacent to the target or target group (the capture of the king in Hnefatafl can be seen as an example of this as well, or a double case of Custodianship). Intervention is the inverse of Custodianship but Parlett provides no examples. Leap is capturing by moving over the target, as for example is done in Draughts (line leaps allow several target to be capture simultaneously; long leaps do not require that either the starting or stopping space is adjacent to the target). Approach is capturing by moving adjacent to the target while Withdrawal is capturing by moving away from it (Parlett mentions Fanorona as an example of both). More ways are possible (e.g. Reflection and Telekinesis) but have rarely been used.

Even given one of these ways of <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style>, the game design must support some action that facilitates it. <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> favor the use of <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, promoting <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> and through that <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, but can also make use of <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style>. In the case of <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style> is typical as is  <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style>, both promoting skills in <style="Link"><link="dexterity-based-actions">Dexterity-Based Actions</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> usually has the subgoal of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style> (but <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Qix">Qix</link></style> shows as an example of using <style="Link"><link="enclosure">Enclosure</link></style>) while <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> commonly have subgoals such as <style="Link"><link="alignment">Alignment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enclosure">Enclosure</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="configuration">Configuration</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Connection">Connection</link></style>. Those that have <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> as the way to achieve <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> can modulate the difficulty of performing the action by using <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>.

Parlett also mentions Conversion, which is the Transfer of Control of a game element to another players and which can be used as a modifier to any of the Capture methods listed (Reversi is an example of this), and conflates Capture with Gain Ownership. Another possible modifier is Huffing, allowing Units that could have captured but did not to themselves be captured. Parlett also notes that a Capture can be immediate (the most common case), or be a Delayed Effect that can open up for making it an Interruptible Action (as is argued to exist by those reconstructing the rules of Ludus Latrunculorum).

The action pattern <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> is a more specific form of <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> and typically used for <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, especially those using <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style>. It can be used to instantiate <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> but using other means allows less aggressive diegetic explanations of why game elements are removed, and what happens to them after they are removed. Designing <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> can for most cases be seen as choosing between whether to use <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, but can in both cases be seen as a struggle over <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals can easily be added to make <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> goals more difficult, this makes others than those controlling a game element want to protect it and create <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> can make a good candidate for <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style> since the reason for the goal can easily be given diegetic explanations through the desires of <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>.

To provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Smooth%20Learning%20Curves">Smooth Learning Curves</link></style>, game interfaces can use <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> to show which <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> are under threat to be <style="CurrentLink">Captured</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> is a common ways of providing <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> in games, and are also very often related to <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals in the <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style>. Since the action is connected to individual game elements, the pattern is often a <style="Link"><link="abilities">Ability</link></style> (but <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> can be seen as example of a game with <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> without having it associated with specific game elements). The pattern also typically causes <style="Link"><link="preventing-goals">Preventing Goals</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> for those controlling the targeted <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. The control of a new game element through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style> after a <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> can give <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, possibly <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, but can also trigger retaliating <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> goals for the previous owner. How all these related to each other depends primarily on their individual <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style> structures and on players' tactics. However, since <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can typically <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> each other, all <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> belonging to one players can work against another play and thereby work as <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> as long as they are <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> goals focused upon the things delivered as part of <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style> goals cause <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals for those with the <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style> goals.

<style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> can modulate <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style> goals by being triggered when those that have <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals have fail so that they have a chance of restoring their initial <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals. Similarly, <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> makes <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style> more important due to the added <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> possible if mistakes are done.

<style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> depends on <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> but for <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> is more often required, as players have to take other <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> actions into consideration due to <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> combined with <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> of game elements that are <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style> can quicken gameplay as fewer game elements remain and promote <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style> since each element represents a greater part of players' <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> can lead to <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> if one has to try and catch those with <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals and these have <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>; likewise those with <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goals can have <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> if those with <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> goals have <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>.

Quite naturally, successful captures can lead to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Element%20Removal">Game Element Removal</link></style> especially when <style="CurrentLink">Capture</style> is instantiated through <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="interruptible-actions">Interruptible Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-movement">Privileged Movement</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style>
